number of helpful: 66 of 73 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 31, 2014
												Imagine a puzzle game where logic is thrown out fo the window, and absurdity is rewarded - that's McPixel. McPixel, the 'hero', is faced with various different scenarios where he is tasked with saving the day, often from a bomb. There's only one way to save the day in each scenario, but it'll often take trial and error to discover it. It often won't make sense, but it will more often than not be absurd and strangely funny.The McPixel website describes it best "You have 20 seconds to solve each riddle, regardless whether you lose or fail, you will be transported to next puzzle that you haven't solved yet."While it might take several attempts (and in some cases a lot of click and hope) to discover the correct way to solve the puzzle, the game rewards you, and in some ways encourages you to find all the different endings to each scenario. If you find them all you unlock the an extra round of scenarios in each level. The game is entirely based around using the mouse, and clicking on the various objects within a scenario to trigger the outcome. There's little more to it than that, so in a stragne way it would make a great iOS game and I think I would have enjoyed it in a more casual pick up and play basis in 10 minute bursts. Having said that I did stomach it enough to sit through it all and finish the game within 2 hours, and then attempt the 'Free DLC'. There's plenty of pop culture references and humour to keep you engaged if you're something of a 'nerd' (I know I found them entertaining). However, the game becomes slightly derailed towards the end with just how unlogical and absurd the puzzles become. In some cases there's no real way of discovering how to save the world without a good old fashioned hopeless clicking everywhere on the screen frezy. I enjoyed it for the crazy nature of the game, however the soundtrack might just put some people off as there's only really one track that repeats throughout the game. In short, a crazy puzzle game that might not be for everyone depending on your absurdity threshold. I'll recommend it as I enjoyed it, but I can see why some people might not. Not for everyone. Probably best to check out the free demo available on the website: http://mcpixel.net/ or on Steam.

The game is structured very creatively to keep you on your toes the whole way through. Lots of levels and easter eggs. Legitimately funny, laugh-out-loud humor that ranges from subtle to asinine.CONS: Disappointed by the lack of achievements, but that's a very small gripe in the grand scheme of things.WORTH: You can get about 5 hours or so of play out of it, which is pretty good for a game that you can get for the price of a candy bar.OVERALL: Gaming is riddled with failed attempts at comedy. number of helpful: 40 of 61 people (66%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												A light hearted wonderful game with a great sense of humour.McPixel is a fast paced indie game that stars “McPixel” a strange character that goes around saving the day from all things explosive!You are thrown into various different situations in various different settings and given 20 seconds to save the day, how that turns out is down to you and your fast thinking. It is not at all a serious game and it’s very likely that 95% of the time you will blow something up on your first try. But it’s still fun none the less and the level comes back around faster than you can even think about it. It has a somewhat crude but hilarious sense of humour, with very bizarre gags in each stage.There was quite a few times during my time playing that I just thought, “Who the hell would do that?” and had a little chuckle to myself.  But there you go, that is the magic and charm of McPixel.The music is extremely repetitive, but strangely enough it isn’t annoying. It’s more catchy then annoying.The main game is pretty short and there is a load of free DLC for you to play afterwards if you want to. (So there are a lot of days to save!)If you were to play this nonstop the whole thing would probably take you a few hours, and it’s probably a good idea to take breaks due to its fast paced nature.Generally I really enjoyed it; I thought it was pretty fun; there are a lot of references and things to have a laugh at in this game. So it’s something fun to throw on when you are bored.

												It's amusing and cheap, always a winning combination, but I'm far from impressed outside of a chuckle here and there. A parody of MacGyver and other unrealistic action heroes, the game has you defuse the danger in various scenarios by, well, clicking on everything on screen in hopes to find the order that works. And that's where McPixel falls short, there is no gameplay, per se. There is no internal logic to decipher, nothing to understand. Click a character or set piece. If nothing happens (that's good), click another one. If♥♥♥♥♥♥blows up, start over with a new order of clicking-on-things. It's basically a time consuming way to play out a bunch of jokes.

number of helpful: 36 of 57 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2013
												MCPIXEL was shockingly enjoyable and entertaining. To break it down for you, its a point and click puzzle game set in brief different scenarios, such as in a falling elevator, you need to analyze how to save the day. You have  an emergency button, elevator buttons, an old man, a bell hop and an extinguisher. What do you do to save the day? These are wacky and weird situations, usually involving bombs or gasoline. None of which lasts no longer than 15 seconds. The game is broken up into 4 chapters, each chapter has 3 or so clusters of 6 scenarios / challenges. If you fail doing a challenge, you don't do it over and over until you get it right, you just go to the next uncompleted scenario.I completed the entire first chapter in about 15 minutes, which is 18 challenges? There is free DLC, which is a series of selectable clusters made by fans or whomever. There is a lot of content here, but the real catch is the challenges just don't last a long time. They're pretty easy to figure out.The cherry on top of this is that there are some laugh out loud results. Maybe the results are so LOL because they're so unexpectedly random. Again, I expected nothing from this game and got a lot of entertainment from it. I'll be returning to the game to see the other quirky scenarios with crude graphics.

number of helpful: 12 of 14 people (86%) found this review helpful11 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												Playing McPixel is pretty much like being drunk. Everything seems like a good idea.The wild gameplay, that awards not only the correct solutions but also failed attempts, requires a great deal of creativity. Creativity - not just random clicking on every single pixel on your screeen, as many have pointed out in their reviews. After a time, the game begins to draw you towards its twisted logic. The bumpy run you had the first time playing McPixel, turns out to be very addictive, definately re-playable and captivating long ride.The humour used by the creators is a little bit foul, sure. You will feel it pays tribute to your inner 14-year-old. It fits, however, the randomness and roughness of the game, making you smirk at the most obscure gags. (And is still better than American Pie.) What is even more exciting, the game has been provided with themed levels, for example paying tribute to other famous video games.Also, lots of explosions.

												Short, trial and error, point and click puzzles in an old-school pixelated style.  Reminds me of Wario Ware type games (although plays a bit different but same 20 second time frames). You will fail time and again (you actually have to fail to see all the possible results to open some bonus rounds) but not particularly frustrating as it is very quick paced but casual. content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												I have the faintest of suspicions that I may be "getting old".  The fact that this game is frankly too silly for even the immature likes of me seems to bear this out.  That, and the fact that while I was fine with all the post, and indeed post-post, and probably even post-post-post, and maybe, just maybe, even all the post-post-post-post-modernist humour that has emerged during my lifetime, all this post-post-post-post-post-modernist humour that seems all the rage these days is just a bit beyond me, I'm afraid.  Half the time, not only did I not find the "gags" of this game all that funny, but at least another quarter of the time I didn't even understand what had just transpired (though the insanely, even downright PERVERSELY pixelated nature of events may not have helped in these instances).  The other quarter of the time, okay, I got myself a cheap chuckle - my personal favourite was trying to work out who the virgin was to throw in the volcano, and ultimately (and successfully) deciding on MYSELF - but the laughs really are too few and far between to put up with the eye-bleedingly awful graphics and incredibly limited gameplay.  (Groovy music, though.)    Look, I will recommend it, but only just, and only to those who need a brief break from watching allegedly "funny♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; all day, every day on ♥♥♥♥ing YOUTUBE.  Yes, it's at roughly THAT level, I'm afraid.  Enjoy your LOLs, kiddies... Verdict: 6/10.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												This is actually a trial and error game; click the right things in the right order to prevent an explosion. If you fail, you have to do the other levels in the chapter first. At the end of the chapter, the game lets you retry the failed levels, until you completed them all. Then you proceed to the next chapter. You have to memorize the things you have already tried, so you can try something different the next time you play that level. There are some silly and amusing jokes here and there but in the end I didn't really enjoy this game that much. I just got bored fast. At least on PC. I think this game is much more suitable for mobile platforms, to play in short bursts, to kill some time with. And guess what... McPixel is actually available on mobile platforms! You can buy the game for Android and iPhone. I wish Steam would offer an option to review a game with a sort of neutral verdict. Because as a mobile game, I would actually say yes. But this is Steam and we are reviewing Steam games here. As a PC game, it just doesn't work for me.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												Haven't laughed this hard in a while! McPixel plays with your expectations and makes it hardly ever possible to anticipate how an interaction will turn out: Will your character pick a thing up if you click it? Will he break it? Will he just kick it until it explodes? - Who knows, let's try! And while this may sound random and frustrating it's totally fine since the game expects you to fail and fail often. Your time is never wasted, transitions can be skipped at will, so it's always tempting and motivating to give it just one more try - and probably laugh your♥♥♥♥♥off. Highly recommended.

												Short, twenty-second puzzles in which you try to help McPixel save the world... or at least, the world he's in... with a couple of well-placed clicks. 												Ok, so I'm recommending this, but honestly I'd suggest picking it up for less than 5 bucks if you can. 												I got this game on sale for next to nothing. For what I got it for, I'd say it was worth it.It's a simple point and click adventure where the solution you're looking for is not always apparent.It has some interesting humor, and can be fun if you just wanna sit down, zone out, and play something for a couple minutes without getting to into it. It does what it does well, and should be commended for that.It has free DLC, and user created levels, you can even create a level yourself and share it with others! Aspects like this can keep the game interesting far after you have went through and beaten it, even after going through and getting everything that can happen in a scenario.While I got this dirt cheap, I'd definitly recommend you get this one on sale, or wait for it to go on sale. I don't quite think it's worth the initial asking price for what it is, since you can find games similar to it for free on various websites.Worth a buy if you can get it for next to nothing. Posted: October 3, 2014
												Spoof 8 bit version of the 80's TV show "McGuyver" where you must stop a bomb exploding withing 20 seconds. It's fun in short bursts (the way it is meant to be played - it even says so on the loading screen) and it is incredible random. One screen clicking on a man might make him open his mouth, the next it might make him fall off a building, you never know, so it's basically trial and error to hit on the correct solution. However, if you get it wrong, you usually get a quick laugh along with the chance to replay the level again. Plus it comes with tons of bonus free DLC, so if you are looking for a quick palette cleanser to play between games, McPixel might do the trick.

Posted: July 19, 2013
												Did you ever watch the "McGrubber" sketch at Saturday Night Live? It's a parody of the '80s TV series "McGyver", which features a man who can basically disable any single bomb using the simpler things, like a rubber band or a paper clip.This game carries the parody even further, mixing scenarios of many pop culture TV series, books, movies and games, with the most absurd solutions.The game only needs you to click on something - up to three or four things, but mostly just one - to solve the scenario and save the day. If you clicked the correct thing then the bomb will be disabled; if not, then it will blow up and you'll lose the scenario. However, most of the scenarios have their own logic, and you have to think out of the hat to choose the correct answer.It's a fun game, but really short. Anyway it will make you laugh in more than one way.It's totally worth the $0.99 price tag that it has right now in the summer sale, so if you can spare a dollar you should consider this among your options.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												This is a silly, silly point-and-click game where you try to figure out how to stop a bomb from exploding through trial and error.  The graphics are intentionally (I think?) super crude, and the interactions between you (McPixel) and world objects are surreal and unpredictable, which gives the game its charm and character.  The game wisely advises you to play it in short sittings and take breaks.  Indeed, I found if I played more than one set of levels at a time the humor would kind of wear off, and since this game relies entirely on its humor, it stopped being fun very quickly.  But then when I played it the next day it'd be fresh again.  Some drawbacks: The music is repetitive; the graphics are overly crude, so much so that you can't always tell a clickable object exists; there's no achievements (I'm a little OCD so I like achievements).  I think it's a little pricey at $5, but I bought it on sale so I think it was definitely worth whatever it was I paid.  All in all, it's a quirky, silly game that  changes the entire genre  will put a smile on your face.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
												McPixel reminds me of the poptarts commercials that end with the guy saying "Craaazy good!", which has almost nothing to do with this game.The whole point of the game is to click things in scenarios, sometimes in different combinations, to make different outcomes. They really make sure to include everything, there are plenty of different outcomes for each scene and the only way to 100% them is to produce every single scenario. Its a fun and easy enough game that I 100%ed all of the levels and had a good laugh. For $1, it was certainly worth the purchase! Very funny, and I think probably appropriate for all ages.Overall: 6/10 (I mean, it exceeded its purpose, for what it is!)

content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
Short version: 77%An absurd and sometimes obscene puzzle game that focuses on short visual gags and the most illogical solutions one can find to a problem. The strangest thing is that it works quite well either as a good bad game or just as a clever indie puzzle– with an excellent length/price ratio thanks to the continuous release of free new levels.Long version:McPixel is the kind of game that you can hardly place anywhere. On one hand it’s obviously a joke title, full of obscene and sometimes downright retarded gags, completely illogical puzzles and an utterly insane basic idea: you have to defuse bombs at unusual places (including a lot of video game or movie themed levels) using the most absurd ways.Still, despite the complete absence of logic, it works surprisingly well as a puzzle game, and the incentives to find all possible solutions can open up a few clever visual gags that really show how great imagination the creator has. It may not be a new Portal in terms of advancing puzzle games to the next level, but it offers a quick fun, and thanks to the many levels– including the free DLCs and community-created ones– it can last quite long, if you choose to stick with it.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
												What happens when you combine MacGyver, point and click, and fast paced insane logic? Well, you get McPixel, a game that isn’t afraid to throw logic out the window and give some straightforward jokes.McPixel is a game that can be described as “WarioWare meets point and click adventure”. Each scene has a 20 second timer, with McPixel trying to save the day, often by disarming a bomb. Actions range from moving, picking up objects, and interacting with objects. Given the short time limit to solve the situation, players will tend to combine as many objects as possible. The game’s crazy logic behind the puzzles don’t tend to make sense and often the solutions are found by trial and error, though there are some more sane solutions that can be found. Solving each scene is simple, but the gameplay assists in something bigger, which is the game content itself.In this game, McPixel must save the day. How he does so depends on the scene and the criteria for doing so is often stretched. Throughout the game, various gags are presented, often with random and crazy ideas. Often some gross out humor is applied, so be aware of the random jokes and occasional bodily functions. Along with these kinds of gags, many pop culture references are in the game, especially with TV and video games. These references I feel tend to work better at giving a good laugh, though the various random occurrences that don’t reference anything also are worth a laugh. Anyway, the bulk of the game is in its humor, and McPixel has no shortage of comedy to toss around and make you laugh.On a short note, the game applies a retro style with its art and music. The game is pixelated like an old game, though McPixel does employ a consistent and certain character style. Scenery tends to be pixel art as well, or in some cases pixelated versions of photographs. Animations are crucial to delivering the game’s gags, and the crazy qualities of them work fine with the retro style. Music is the same way as well, using some chiptunes for some nice fat beats. There are not many songs and the tracks are quite short, but it does achieve the retro style with some neat chiptunes.McPixel is a game for those looking to laugh at the absurd and crazy situations and interactions. Gameplay is kept simple to focus on delivering comedy, though the game’s crazy logic can make some puzzles confusing and require trial and error. Still, with some retro styling with the art and music mimicking old video games, McPixel makes for a game to laugh at some silly things.

												The concept is simple: click on various things in the environment, chaining the actions together so your character can diffuse a bomb. However, it's completely random. There is no hint whatsoever as to what will give you success, and what will end with you just kicking an NPC in the nuts (which is about 40% of the time). Most games allow you to make /something/, but McPixel is all about admiring what the devs have already done.

number of helpful: 38 of 75 people (51%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												In my 17 years of gaming, never have I come across a game that is so bad. It is basically a point and click game. The aim of the game is to locate and destroy/get rid of a bomb by clicking on objects on the screen. There are several stages which each has several levels.The good points are that you get lots of levels (100) which you can happily sink alot of time in.Now for the bad points. First off, although the game tries to be humorous by having you embarass or do terrible things to the characters in the game, some of the actions that the main character does may be offend/disturb people (e.g. peeing on an alien). Second is that when you start the game there is literally no tutorial which was somewhat frustrating trying to figure out what to do. Third issue is that when you fail to locate the bomb, you will proceed to the next level. The game then goes through all five levels of the stage untill you have disarmed the bomb in each stage. This forces you to remember exactly which items not to click on, but the main problem is that it is somewhat difficult to find which items can be interacted with. Fourth issue is that the game is extremely repetitive. Once you finished the first level, all the other levels are exactly the same except with new scenery. Fifth issue is that the music is really annoying as it plays 1 track for the ENTIRE game.If you like point and click games, avoid this game. If you like a fun and enjoyable games, avoid this game. It isn't even worth $1 let alone $5.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2013
												Incredibly stupid gameplay mixed with incredible stupid puzzle solutions - you've got the best puzzle game of 2013!McPixel is a fast paced humorous mini-puzzle game, where our main hero McPixel (an obvious reference to Macgyver) tries in 20 seconds to defuse a bomb and save the day. Everything is controlled with one mouse button and that's where it's charm lies. To use or pick up an item you just press it. And hope for the best. Sometimes pressing something (or someone) will pick that thing or even a person up to use with other items. In other cases, pressing will lead to McPixel kicking the said item or person. Usually that kick will result in everything blowing up.Sometimes the solution is to press on the fire to take your pants off and take a♥♥♥♥♥♥ saving everyone's life. Pressing the fire in the next puzzle will make McPixel jump to the fire, combusting himself. In the third puzzle, pressing the bomb will make McPixel kick it, destroying half the city. The solutions range from simply press the fire extinguisher to extinguish bomb to kick a fat naked guy in the showers, so that he would slip on the soap and land on a bomb, defusing it.Every single solutions is stupid, yet brilliant at the same time.It also offers FREE DLC, a thing that you wouldn't get in a 60$ "realistic millitary shooter". And for a such a minimal price, you'd be an idiot not to try this game out.RECOMMENDED TO BUY.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												McPixel, the king of gag games. A parody, unto a parody of a parody in a parodying universe. Parodyception ladies and gentlemen.McPixel is a very simple premise, find a way to stop a bomb from blowing up in less than twenty seconds. Sometimes it's easy, requiring one or two steps, but sometimes you'll wrack your brain trying to figure out what the hell to do.The controls are point and click, no ifs ands or buts. I took this game down in little over two hours play-time on my tablet, and have since not touched it (with good reason). After beating all the levels, finding all the gags, and playing the bonus levels, there really isn't much to do, unless you're into custom player levels.All the gags are cheesy, including having McPixel kick people, or♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥on something, humping a PS3... you get the idea. Honestly, while I got a laugh out of a few of them, most of the gags made me want to gag.All in all, if you need to pass time, get this on Play Store, the App Store, or any mobile device, but not here. Play it though, at least once.

Posted: January 2, 2014
												McPixel is hard to review, but here's my attempt:McPixel is a point and click adventure, in which you are thrust into a random world and forced to defuse some random situation in less than 3 seconds.  If you make the wrong choice, you fail that scenario.  But don't worry, you will fail many scenarios, as the correct path is hardly ever the most obvious.  And that's the charm of the game.  You essentially try these situations over and over, and you'll finally realize that you aren't supposed to pick up the dynamite you're supposed to kick the guy in his genitals (duh!)This game reeks of potty humor, and slapstick comedy, and I find it hilarious!For the steam sale price, it's definitely worth picking up.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												McPixel is probably the closest thing to experiencing an actual mental break from reality, and that's fine because who likes boring old reality anyway? As random as the game seems, there's some sort of weird, reverse anti-backwards logic that keeps multiple levels of using guess and check on a bunch of random game elements fun and satisfying. It has the feeling of being what a point and click adventure game would be like if instead of saying "I can't do that" every time you rubbed two random, unrelated objects together, your character did whatever dumb thing came to mind first with them. With the ability to also create your own simplistic levels with some patience and frame by frame animating, you can pretty much make any of your gleeful childish jokes and obscure references a reality. Although McPixel isn't for everyone, give it a go if you still have the mindset to enjoy immature humor.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												McPixelThe oddest, weirdest take on Wario Ware I've seen in years. Retro chunk pixelly graphics, 8 bit soundtrack, and a series of vignettes where you're McPixel trying to stop an explosion. Again & again & again, in weirder & weirder sub 30 second gameplay sequences. Fail, and it's onto the next one in the sequence, looping back to failures after about 6 or so. It's a weird mix of Wario Ware meets a 2D point & click (there's an interaction puzzle to solve on each one) & a weird nasty Flash pixelly game.All with a heavy dose of Jackass humour.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2013
												Buy? Maybe. (My experience is based on the Android version) McPixel is a very stupid minigame-fest, where you must save the day by preventing a bomb from exploding in a variety of 20 scenarios. The idea is a sort of comedy based, retro-style take on MacGuyver, where you improvise a way to stop a bomb from exploding. This includes stuffing bombs into people, causing somebody to accidentally kick the bomb out, or straight up urniating on the bomb. The comedy overtly crude and immature, and probably the reason for it's popularity of "Let's Play" videos with the younger audience. There are a few moments of laughs for me, especially the "Insert Virigin" mission.It's point and click adventure gameplay will unfairly throw people off - unlike most adventure games where you may find yourself stuck without a guide, this is the only adventure point and click I know of where there is a constant failure state built in either the 20 second time limit of each level or in your inability to find the right answer. Plus, the extreme simplicity of the controls where you can either click to interact or swipe/right click to skip removes unnecessary complexity from the genre. Yes, it's a tad annoying to fail, but it's over quickly and since you can only click on so few things, you will eventually find the answer. This alone makes this game worth playing or at least checking out to people with huge backlogs - the game is very short (3-5hrs) and it means you can play the game, even mindlessly and be able to finish without scratching your head very often (there are a couple head scratchers though). There are no sound effects in the entire game beyond the title screen. It's strange how a game about explosions only uses it in the title screen versus the rest of the game. It could have been a conscious decision to let the zany, silly chiptune style music make the situation seem crazy, lazy game design, or possibly both. The biggest legimate annoyance is the humor of the game♥♥♥♥♥♥jokes, dry humping, crotch kicks - it all sounds like something written by a pre-teen and it will definitely annoy some people. Another very annoying aspect is having to replay level to "find all the gags" in every level before you can reach the ending. This may offer some entertainment to players that enjoy this comedy, but for everybody else, it's an unnecessary grind, which is accentuated in the irritatingly boring, and unnecessary "click everything and hope for the best" last level. Still, I'd say the $5 price tag matches the value of the game, though I'm glad I got this in a bundle which made it really cheap - I could say I wasted my time with this game, but I played it on my phone while there was down time at work - wasting time was the whole point.By the way, I'd argue this game is better in short bursts on a mobile device than sitting down and playng on PC. The only reason why I have 10 hours logged was to farm trading cards - I wouldn't have installed it otherwise.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2013
												Incredibly stupid gameplay mixed with incredible stupid puzzle solutions - you've got the best puzzle game of 2013!McPixel is a fast paced humorous mini-puzzle game, where our main hero McPixel (an obvious reference to Macgyver) tries in 20 seconds to defuse a bomb and save the day. Everything is controlled with one mouse button and that's where it's charm lies. To use or pick up an item you just press it. And hope for the best. Sometimes pressing something (or someone) will pick that thing or even a person up to use with other items. In other cases, pressing will lead to McPixel kicking the said item or person. Usually that kick will result in everything blowing up.Sometimes the solution is to press on the fire to take your pants off and take a♥♥♥♥♥♥ saving everyone's life. Pressing the fire in the next puzzle will make McPixel jump to the fire, combusting himself. In the third puzzle, pressing the bomb will make McPixel kick it, destroying half the city. The solutions range from simply press the fire extinguisher to extinguish bomb to kick a fat naked guy in the showers, so that he would slip on the soap and land on a bomb, defusing it.Every single solutions is stupid, yet brilliant at the same time.It also offers FREE DLC, a thing that you wouldn't get in a 60$ "realistic millitary shooter". And for a such a minimal price, you'd be an idiot not to try this game out.RECOMMENDED TO BUY.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												McPixel is the epitomy of "lol so randumb XD" type humor. While each stage is short and simple enough to figure out fairly quickly, each situation makes pretty much no sense, and the solution even less so; old Sierra point-and-click adventure games were more coherent. I would say it's usable as a quick laugh, but even the gags and jokes throughout are generally juvenile and unfunny ("haha the L on the sign for Pool fell off so it says poo hahahaha"). While "random" humor has its place and can provide a good chuckle, it rapidly loses its potency when it's mercilessly pounded into your skull every 5 seconds.Pass.

Posted: August 6, 2014
												The game is short! On the other hand, had it been any longer, it wouldn't have suffered through it till I beat it, as everything about it is sub-par.- The Graphics: I'm all for old-school big pixels. But this game demonstrates that even such a crude style needs a competent artist to be good. In McPixel, many times, it was impossible to see what object a big blot of pixels was supposed to represent. On average, everything that appeared on screen was ugly. - The Audio: There are no sound effects and the music is repetitive and irritative. - Mechanisms: McPixel is a string of short adventure game-style sections in which you need to solve "puzzles" within 20 seconds. A solution typically requires one to three clicks on the various objects in the scene, and follows no logic whatsoever. I'm not talking alternative logic, Antichamber-style. I'm talking 100% random sequences of clicks. yuk Should you try any other sequence than the right one, you lose.- Timing: The scenes come in groups of 6. You try scene 1 once, then, no matter if you won or lost, you try scene 2... After scene 6 you go back to the first scene that you haven't won yet. The cycle goes on until all six scenes are won. The problem is that such short sequences are separated by transition segments that last several seconds. You can skip them with a right-click, but it's tedious any way.- Humor: Almost all combinations of clicks in a scene, no matter how "right" or "wrong" they are, cause a little animation that tries to be funny. I think in the whole game, two or three of them made me smile. The rest was just complete, random nonsense. Not the funny nonsense you'd find in a Monty Python comedy or the poetic nonsense of Lewis Caroll. Just whatever dull and/or gross stuff crossed the developer's mind.I won't give it the lowest score possible because it was short enough and make me grin for at least 20 seconds, but this is not a game I would recommend to any sober individual. There is zero chance I'll try any of the bonus stuff like hidden gags or "free DLC" or whatever.Rating: 3 out of 10

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20
												First 15 min Impressions: McPixelVerdict: Pass if you're over 12 years oldImagine Warioware. Now imagine Warioware without the art, and replaced with really crappy pixel art. Now take that, and play it with a mouse and keyboard. Now take away the silly humor, and replace it with an endless sea of sodomy jokes. Now make it suck, and make it frustrating to play. Add a crappy 10 second audio clip that plays endlessly.You're left with something like McPixel.Gameplay proceeds in rounds, in which you are given 20 seconds to find/defuse a bomb. There are only a limited number of items on the screen you can click, and clicking on them in the wrong order makes the bomb explode. There doesn't seem to be any logic to how to diffuse the bombs, though you can usually get through by trying to make the crudest joke possible with the items you can click on. Solve 6 of these puzzles playing on endless repeat, and you can solve another 6 until you want to throw up.This is a game you would play on the library computer when your teacher wasn't looking in middle school, where you'd inevitably get busted anyway because you were laughing at the dumb and crude jokes. Outside any other context, there is no reason to ever play this game.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												McPixel is the epitomy of "lol so randumb XD" type humor. While each stage is short and simple enough to figure out fairly quickly, each situation makes pretty much no sense, and the solution even less so; old Sierra point-and-click adventure games were more coherent. I would say it's usable as a quick laugh, but even the gags and jokes throughout are generally juvenile and unfunny ("haha the L on the sign for Pool fell off so it says poo hahahaha"). While "random" humor has its place and can provide a good chuckle, it rapidly loses its potency when it's mercilessly pounded into your skull every 5 seconds.Pass.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2013
												Представьте: сотня комнат. В каждой бомба, которую нужно разминировать за 20 секунд. Ваш герой – красный прямоугольник с пузиком в джинсах ходит вокруг и пинает предметы. Если он не успеет ткнуть в нужные вещи в необходимой последовательности, комнату разорвет, а игра включит следующую. Потом еще одну, еще, еще, еще, еще, потом опять первую (из-за повторов McPixel немножко напоминает 8-ми битную версию фильма "Исходный код").Все упрощено до предела. Мир из гигантских пикселей. В каждой комнате всего три-четыре предмета. Например: змея, бомба, иллюминатор и дверь. Или: девственница, кость и корова. Большинство задач решается перебором и очень часто до того, как вы догадаетесь, что здесь происходит вообще. "Клик, клик, клик" – комната пройдена.Из-за графики часть предметов не различима. Серое пятно с дедушкой на мосту, зеленый квадратик на кладбище, я бы наверное улыбнулся, если бы знал, что кидаю в могилу. Почему мой герой только что нассал на пришельца? Игра не объясняет – “клик, клик, клик”.Все это можно пройти за 40 минут, хотя приестся быстрее. В самом начале здесь даже пишут "Не играйте подолгу".P.S.: Многое объясняет и то, что с самого начала McPixel сделали на iOS и Android. Тут и правда эталонный туалетный геймплей для сессий по пять минут.

												This game...Well, if you're a fan of 5 second YouTube videos this may be for you. It's pretty much a game where you just click on one or two things and wish for the best of luck. If you fail, guess what? You go and do it again, but click the other things! Maybe this game wasn't for me? Possibly. For ages 10 and under, this game may be fun for you, but everyone 11+, avoid it. However, you'll get a few laughs in by forcing your friends to play it, so I'm on the fence about recommending/discouraging this to others. For a $1 sale, go for it. $5? Absolutely not. My friend, Corey, gave it a 3/10 after me telling him to play it on my account, but I'll give it a 4.5/10

number of helpful: 21 of 42 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
												McPixel is a point and click adventure game in a WarioWare-like situation where your character is attempting to prevent a bomb (or other device) from blowing up. This is played out by interacting with various objects in the game which usually have completely unpredictable results.This is not a terribly fun game. Ultimately, while you "control" the outcome, there's no real way to determine "right" or "wrong" - it's all trial and error until you find the idea which the designer thought would be the funny actual solution. Half the time they're not all that funny in the first place. Additionally, the game is quite short - it takes longer to run the game to drop all the steam trading cards than it does to beat the game itself, literally.If I'm not mistaken, this game was originally a phone game and is far better suited to that format - clicking the screen, seeing stuff happen, and consuming in very, very bite sized increments. As a PC game where you're generally sitting down for somewhat longer play sessions, the novelty wears thin very rapidly and it becomes more tedious then entertaining.

number of helpful: 9 of 19 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												If there is any game I will never install again on Steam, it is McPixel. The main essence of the game is to explore a variety of "jokes" in a certain area and then defuse a bomb before it goes off. If you die, then you go to the next area, and so on and so on until all bombs are defused. It's a tedious process to go through. The levels themselves are boring, the jokes lame, and if you're looking for a game that requires you to not lose brain cells, there's even a warning of sorts telling you that you will lose your brain cells (Which is the only funny thing about the game because it's true). There's extra levels that follow the same concept, and while they're free they just aren't worth playing, just like the entire game in general. The graphics give a slightly retro effect to it but doesn't match with how you navigate the levels for my playing experience. If anyone really likes this game, I have three cards for sale that are three cents each, go ahead and take them off my hands (Offer now void)

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												The idea behind McPixel is that you get placed into a random situation wherein you have to stop a bomb from going off through point-and-click puzzling. The situations and their solutions are rather obtuse, so working through them is often trial-and-error. This would be fine if the game held up in other ways, but quite frankly the game's attempts at humor -- usually very crude violence or excrement jokes -- fall flat for me and the aesthetics are equally bland unless you're into the occasional pixelated parody. I bought this on sale expecting at least a few laughs, but I ended up just being frustrated. I suggest buying a sandwich or a candy bar instead -- those would bring more enjoyment than this.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												In this point-and-click adventure game, you play rounds consisting of multiple locations, each with a bomb you have to defuse. The logic of defusing the bomb rarely makes sense, but that was probably a part of the failed attempt at humor in this game. You die a lot as a result of this and also because most actions kill you instantly. This was extremely frustrating at first, but after discovering I could skip the tediously long cut scenes at the start and end of each location, the game was no longer tedious, boring, and frustrating, but only tedious and boring!  The fun of Kicking people in the groin or peeing on them wears off after the first level. I feel like it’s inappropriate to review a game you spent only an hour playing, but I just have no desire to return to the game right now.If you’re a fan of tedious shallow gameplay or lackluster humor, then you might enjoy this game.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2015
												McPixel is a point and click game adventure game.  Although enjoying very few point-and-click games, I was willing to give a chance to.  In the end, I did not find myself having a fun experience.The game is meant to be a comedy of sorts, having both slapstick and crass humor.  Although some of the gags are good, the logic behind solving the puzzles is convoluted and confusing, sometimes having no logic at all.  This results in you usually having to just use trial and error over and over to figure out the right order of operations to solve a level.  This is made somewhat less annoying, however, as the load times between failed attempts is very quick.  In my opinion, the gameplay would better fit a more narrative driven game than a rapid-paced puzzle game.The other problem I had with the game was the music.  Throughout the entire game, only one very repetitive music track is used.  At least as far as I got, there is no sound effects, ambient noises, voice acting, etc.  This means the one looping music track is the only thing you will hear throughout the entire session.Although I did not find the game fun, players who enjoy "rage games" would probably get a few good laughs out of the game.  I would recommend waiting for a sale however, as there is not much gameplay for a $5.00, compared to other games on Steam for the same (or lower) price.

Posted: October 4, 2012
												McPixel resembles Nintendo's WarioWare really. It's a game filled with mini-games where you're basically given several seconds to complete these mini-games. Now, I can't give you any proper examples because the scenes are just ridiculous(ly absurd) and the same thing goes for the solutions to these 'puzzles'. But in the end it all comes down to stopping a bomb from blowing up. Playing a level will rotate 6 or so mini-games until you have solved them all. Then you move on to the next set if you want.It's a game that should be played in short sessions, and it might actually be more fun on a mobile device, and cheaper as well. Still, since there are no similar games like this for the PC, McPixel is a welcome addition nonetheless.[Rating: 65/100]

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												An insta-fail, counterintuitive, yet enjoyable pixelated point-and-click game. The task is simple: keep the bomb from exploding in various sets of maps and situations.There's not much more about it: every map contains a few characters and environmental elements (some hidden ones too) and you have a few clicks to get the right ones in the right order so your ethically-questionable hero McPixel can take action and throw the bomb away, or shield it, or defuse it and so on.The extremely simple gameplay is weirdly balanced by the major unpredictability of the solution, so you end up frenetically repeating the same set of maps (six every stage) over and over again until you finally get it done.There's also a bonus stage unlocked every time you get a streak of three wins together, but that happens so rarely (unless you're replaying it) that it can be considered a rare event.Of course it can be me: maybe there's actually a pattern by which you can solve all the maps without a doubt, but I couldn't last enough in the game to get it. One reason may be the fact that I couldn't bear gaming sessions longer than 5 or 10 minutes because of the confusion-to-rage inducing solutions and the constantly looping two seconds background 8-bit music (come on...)It's difficult to me to imagine actually completing the entire game, so I can't really figure how one could possibly find the motivation to replay it afterwards.To sum it up, for me it makes an ok game to play when you don't have much time (and something else to listen to), but nothing more.

I thought about giving it a weak recommend, because I don't really REGRET playing it, and most people won't mind the comedy.  But, it seems to me the review should reflect MY take, and the game wasn't quite novel enough (underneath the one try + loop conceit, it's just another point & click), or long enough (even with the "DLC") to merit a recommend.

												I don't get it. I just don't get it. The humor just doesn't get me. It's all weird, dumb slapstick that's, in my opinion, mediocre at best. The gameplay is barely even gameplay. The puzzles don't involve thought, they involve clicking everything on the screen. Bomb in a hotdog stand? Click the cow. One out of every fifteen or so puzzles actually has an answer that makes sense. This game tries so hard to be a "charming indie game," but just comes off monotonous , boring, and quite frankly, dumb. When you're making a game, the actual gameplay should trump filling your game with bad humor and obscure references. If dumb humor is your thing, maybe give this one a shot. Otherwise, stay away. This thing is barely even a game.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												I don't get it. I just don't get it. The humor just doesn't get me. It's all weird, dumb slapstick that's, in my opinion, mediocre at best. The gameplay is barely even gameplay. The puzzles don't involve thought, they involve clicking everything on the screen. Bomb in a hotdog stand? Click the cow. One out of every fifteen or so puzzles actually has an answer that makes sense. This game tries so hard to be a "charming indie game," but just comes off monotonous , boring, and quite frankly, dumb. When you're making a game, the actual gameplay should trump filling your game with bad humor and obscure references. If dumb humor is your thing, maybe give this one a shot. Otherwise, stay away. This thing is barely even a game.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												If you're looking for a couple of laughs with your friends indoors, then sure, this game is for you.However if you are expecting a game that will keep your attention for more than a few minutes, then this game is just going to turn into a donation.I will admit, there are a few laughs hidden throughout this game. But after 10 minutes of just random clicking, it starts to get frustratingly confusing. There is no real incentive to keep on playing - since after completing the various levels, you can go back and "fully complete" levels, by discovering all of the gags. Which really just gets tiresome.There is a "social" (I use that term loosely) aspect of the game, where a bunch of people under the name of the main character just talk to each other.I think the most entertaining part of this game was the "Fart-A-Long". Although even then, there isn't much variety for it as I have played the same 3 patterns (if I recall correctly) numerous times.Is this title worth $5? No. I recieved this game for free, and only played it to retrieve the trading cards from it.But hey, if you're feeling generous and want to have a handfull of amusing moments, then godspeed.2 out of 10 teardrops.TL;DRNo enticement towards replayability, "Social" part of game is just a less-populated version of Omegle, and humor dies out quickly.There are more worthwhile games out there with quite a good incentive for replayability (even under $5.00).

content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												This game isn't all that great.I bought it for $.99 as a cart-topper of sorts while it was on sale, on a mild whim, nothing more. The game is a point-and-click game mashed with Wario Ware quickness.You get about 5 or 6 seconds (give or take a second or two) to "Save The Day" and each level has 5 or 6 scenarios in which McPixel must save the day. It tries to be funny and random, but most often for me it just came off as rather, well, dumb. It's not inherently BAD for what it is, per se, but I wouldn't dare pay full price for this. It's just not really my cup of tea. I mean if you dig point-and-click asthetic and/or WarioWare-esque gameplay, then hell yeah, you'd probably like this. But me, personally, I really don't like it.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												This game... where do I even begin to describe how awesome, addictive, infuriating, intelligent, rage-inducing, beautiful this masterpiece of a game this is. I think having to find the way to save the world, then numeriously blow it up till there literally is no other way to screw up. One of the best things about this game is that once you start you don't stop. once you start a chapter (like 1-1, part 1) you have to finish it. there is no, get 3 right then quit. you have to get them all right to end, but even then it gets better if you start part 2 you have to screw up (about 6 or so times per level). When first playing I was so frustrated that I could barely save the world, but then, I realized that all my screw ups would amount to something, with which makes the game easier (and a heck of a lot more fun) becuase you get to be happy in being correct by punching someone in the face and letting the world blow up (I mean really, if the world was going to end anyways, you might as well punch a person in the face). Highly recommend this game

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												  McPixel may seem stupid and pointless from a distance, but the game game is a BLAST to play (get it? hah!). With plenty of in-game levels and tons of free extra "DLC" to play, you can spend hours with this game. Many of the levels contain a lot of jokes and references to other games or movies, and most of the bonus levels (which you unlock by not only saving the day by defusing the bombs in every level of that chapter, but also going through and discovering all the gags that involve not saving the day) are straight up homages to those things. The video game one was my personal favorite, where you have to save Cloud and Sephiroth by becoming Jenova, and saving Chell from Portal by opening a portal into her body and tossing the bomb in it, etc. I found myself laughing audibly with some of the ridiculous scenes, such as McPixel choosing to dry hump various objects instead of defusing the bomb.   The game menu itself was a delight, each option you pick containing a humorous outcome. The music, though simple was actually quite addicting, and can easily get stuck in your head as it plays in the background of every level that you're trying desperately to defuse a random bomb in less than 20 seconds. Some of the levels were pretty easy, but I don't think the game itself was actually going for a difficulty factor as much as it was a gag factor, and sometimes when the outcome was easy, I actually found myself looking for the funny alternatives instead of defusing the bomb right away. The 8-bit artstylem though simple, actually was very good at depicting the various emotions of the characters, such as McPixel screaming at a soldier to remove the bomb after putting said soldier's own hat on.   I'd definitely recommend this game if you could find it on a sale. As great and amusing as it was, it still only contains about 2 hours of actual gameplay, the rest stemming from DLC both made by the actual developers, and by the community itself via the in-game World Creator. Though than again the game only markets itself as $5, so if you've got a fiver to spend, and have a twisted sense of humor, I think you'd enjoy this game.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2015
												McPixel's is an obnoxious (and proud of it!) point-and-click that tasks you with saving the day in exciting, and some not-so-exciting, situations. Yet another game with a retro aesthetic, and an ugly one at that, McPixel doesn't stand out from the crowd in terms of graphics and sound. The real treat is the gameplay: Defuse the bomb, or at least stop the explosive, but within the allotted time. Otherwise, kaboom! How much time? How's 20 seconds sound?Here's where McPixel really shines: There are tonnes of levels, the developer supports the game like crazy (kudos to Mikolaj "Sos" Kamiński), and the puzzle mechanics are fun. While the humour, as is normally the case, is subjective and can get grating after a while, McPixel works incredibly well in short bursts. Just quit when you feel yourself growing weary, and return when you need another dose of insanity between other games.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												What can be said about McPixel?............Some days you just can't get rid of a bomb.Story- Terrorist have threatend the world and it is up to CIA agent McPixel to... who am I kidding, this game has no story. You are McPixel and you must try to find the bomb and difuse it in humorous (if not nonsensical) ways. One word, wacky. D-Graphics- Quite ugly, even in the retro sense. But done well enough to understand what is going on and get a few laughs on the way. D-Sound- Just the rediculous musical loop that will drive you MAD!!!! D-Gameplay- 10 seconds to find and defuse a bomb. Just point and click, expirament and have fun. C+Overall- Is a fun diversion with plenty of fan generated content, but for the long haul, fails to keep intrest going. That is all I have to say on that so the overall grade, to keep with the random humor of the game. ;-@

content:
Posted: November 23, 2015
												I played this on Android previously but this was my first time on PC. It probably says something about the design that I beat this point-and-click adventure game like a year ago and forgot literally every solution to every puzzle. If you can relax and embrace the game's odd sense of humor, along with the fact that none of the solutions make sense and will require blind trial-and-error to get through, it's an amusing way to kill some time. Recommended, if you're the type of person who can enjoy kicking nuclear bombs and shoving old men down elevator shafts.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2014
												 To be honest, if you think I would suggest this one, you're RIGHT ON TARGET; because that's correct! It's a simple mini-game based point & click adventure game, where each of the levels has 6 scenes, where in each one, you have to figure out within at least 15 seconds, to figure out how to disarm the bomb. (And sometimes, figure out WHERE THE BOMB EVEN IS!) This game is a comedic game; nothing dirty, but rather AWKWARD; the main character is in fact, "McPixel"; a parody of two characters, named MacGyver, and his other parody character, named MacGruber. Each episode is simple; YOU HAVE TO STOP THE BOMB! (Or whatever disaster will happen.) Note that the main hero is not a very smart fellow, so you play as him, (and if lucky) figutre out how to stop a disaster from happening. So, what makes this game so awesome?!? Dude; this game is so dang awkward, that it's funny! If you like a good laugh, and like good, simple "point & click adventure" style puzzle-based gameplay, (that will usually take at least a minute or two, just to solve the puzzles) this game is 100% guaranteed, for a good laugh! Among games that are categorized as "SteamPlay" games, all DLC for this game is FREE! Don't forget; ANYONE can even make their own levels, with the downloadable level editor, too; the official website has a tutorial page that will teach you how it works, because it doesn't require any professional programming knowledge; at least according to what it looks like, of course!

content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												This game... where do I even begin to describe how awesome, addictive, infuriating, intelligent, rage-inducing, beautiful this masterpiece of a game this is. I think having to find the way to save the world, then numeriously blow it up till there literally is no other way to screw up. One of the best things about this game is that once you start you don't stop. once you start a chapter (like 1-1, part 1) you have to finish it. there is no, get 3 right then quit. you have to get them all right to end, but even then it gets better if you start part 2 you have to screw up (about 6 or so times per level). When first playing I was so frustrated that I could barely save the world, but then, I realized that all my screw ups would amount to something, with which makes the game easier (and a heck of a lot more fun) becuase you get to be happy in being correct by punching someone in the face and letting the world blow up (I mean really, if the world was going to end anyways, you might as well punch a person in the face). Highly recommend this game

content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												  McPixel may seem stupid and pointless from a distance, but the game game is a BLAST to play (get it? hah!). With plenty of in-game levels and tons of free extra "DLC" to play, you can spend hours with this game. Many of the levels contain a lot of jokes and references to other games or movies, and most of the bonus levels (which you unlock by not only saving the day by defusing the bombs in every level of that chapter, but also going through and discovering all the gags that involve not saving the day) are straight up homages to those things. The video game one was my personal favorite, where you have to save Cloud and Sephiroth by becoming Jenova, and saving Chell from Portal by opening a portal into her body and tossing the bomb in it, etc. I found myself laughing audibly with some of the ridiculous scenes, such as McPixel choosing to dry hump various objects instead of defusing the bomb.   The game menu itself was a delight, each option you pick containing a humorous outcome. The music, though simple was actually quite addicting, and can easily get stuck in your head as it plays in the background of every level that you're trying desperately to defuse a random bomb in less than 20 seconds. Some of the levels were pretty easy, but I don't think the game itself was actually going for a difficulty factor as much as it was a gag factor, and sometimes when the outcome was easy, I actually found myself looking for the funny alternatives instead of defusing the bomb right away. The 8-bit artstylem though simple, actually was very good at depicting the various emotions of the characters, such as McPixel screaming at a soldier to remove the bomb after putting said soldier's own hat on.   I'd definitely recommend this game if you could find it on a sale. As great and amusing as it was, it still only contains about 2 hours of actual gameplay, the rest stemming from DLC both made by the actual developers, and by the community itself via the in-game World Creator. Though than again the game only markets itself as $5, so if you've got a fiver to spend, and have a twisted sense of humor, I think you'd enjoy this game.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2015
												McPixel's is an obnoxious (and proud of it!) point-and-click that tasks you with saving the day in exciting, and some not-so-exciting, situations. Yet another game with a retro aesthetic, and an ugly one at that, McPixel doesn't stand out from the crowd in terms of graphics and sound. The real treat is the gameplay: Defuse the bomb, or at least stop the explosive, but within the allotted time. Otherwise, kaboom! How much time? How's 20 seconds sound?Here's where McPixel really shines: There are tonnes of levels, the developer supports the game like crazy (kudos to Mikolaj "Sos" Kamiński), and the puzzle mechanics are fun. While the humour, as is normally the case, is subjective and can get grating after a while, McPixel works incredibly well in short bursts. Just quit when you feel yourself growing weary, and return when you need another dose of insanity between other games.

												What can be said about McPixel?............Some days you just can't get rid of a bomb.Story- Terrorist have threatend the world and it is up to CIA agent McPixel to... who am I kidding, this game has no story. You are McPixel and you must try to find the bomb and difuse it in humorous (if not nonsensical) ways. One word, wacky. D-Graphics- Quite ugly, even in the retro sense. But done well enough to understand what is going on and get a few laughs on the way. D-Sound- Just the rediculous musical loop that will drive you MAD!!!! D-Gameplay- 10 seconds to find and defuse a bomb. Just point and click, expirament and have fun. C+Overall- Is a fun diversion with plenty of fan generated content, but for the long haul, fails to keep intrest going. That is all I have to say on that so the overall grade, to keep with the random humor of the game. ;-@

												I played this on Android previously but this was my first time on PC. It probably says something about the design that I beat this point-and-click adventure game like a year ago and forgot literally every solution to every puzzle. If you can relax and embrace the game's odd sense of humor, along with the fact that none of the solutions make sense and will require blind trial-and-error to get through, it's an amusing way to kill some time. Recommended, if you're the type of person who can enjoy kicking nuclear bombs and shoving old men down elevator shafts.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Now i like funny games and consider myself to have a good sense of humour,but come on what the hell is this game all about.I know that graphics dont make a game but they could have helped with this one.You start the first level like every level not really knowing what the "HELL" is going on and what your supposed to do (OH SORRY STOP THE BOMB SILLY ME DUH),and thats the way every level plays out.Its not a question of working out what to do as it is blind luck,and dont do the level right and you get to play it again (OH NO THE PAIN) and then do it wrong again and you get to do it again (WHERES THE EXIT PLEASE),and then you realise that you are just wasting your time and that you know you will get it right eventually as there are not many options left.I didnt enjoy my time with this game (OH MY GOD I DID TRY TO THE POINT OF PURE FRUSTRATION) and i wouldent reccomend it to anyone in a sale or in a bundle.Do like McPixel and find a way to blow this game up (AND IF YOU DONT MANAGE TO KEEP AT IT UNTIL YOU DO) and please dear god dont let there be a sequel.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2015
												I very seldom down-vote a game, but there is no way I can recommend purchasing this.  You're not likely to enjoy this game for long.  I read the reviews ahead of time stating that it's more of a joke than a game."That's okay!" I thought. "Jokes are worth paying for!"  But that's if the joke is good.  Or meatier.  This is one juvenile gag repeated ad nauseam.  Occasionally, the combinations of selecting/kicking result in a good laugh (usually just a chuckle).  The rest...?  Do I enjoy sophomoric humor?  Probably more than I should, but c'mon.  Is there ANYTHING else besides kicking people in the testes and having everything blow up?  The free DLC is all the same.Even if you buy it on sale, run it in the background to get card drops and sell all of them, you won't break even.In short, if you're really interested in this game, see if a friend has it already and play it for 10 minutes on their account.And maybe get really high before playing.  That might help.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												I remember playing this as a Flash game long ago. The retail version is basically the same with more levels. It's a very Warioware-like game. Every stage you get around 30 seconds to save the day (often by stopping a bomb explosion). While the odds of beating a stage the first time are low, there's usually less than 10 permutations you can do on any given stage, so you'll figure it out quickly.Similar to Wizorb, perhaps its best feature is how inexpensive it is - under $1 on a sale. Even less than that if it's in a bundle.If you decide to play and don't feel like reading instructions, just don't forget that SPACE lets you skip just about all animations/intros. It will make your gameplay experience a hundred times better.I finished most of the content, including seeing most of the gags, in about 3 hours. It was.. somewhat fun, I guess. Might have been better left as a Flash game. Still, I'll give it a 6.5 out of 10. Still recommended, but just barely, and only on a sale or in a bundle. Also, if it matters to you, this game has Steam cards.

												I would normally enjoy a random and funny game like this but McPixel goes too far, to the point where it's just stupid. Most of the levels don't require you to think, but more so require you to click randomly. Quite simply the worst 'game' I have ever played. Your time will be spent doing these three things in order of frequency (most often to least):1) Looking at McPixel logos between "levels"2) Randomly touching things on the screen for a few seconds3) wondering where the last 50 seconds of your life wentDo NOT buy this! Even if it is on sale for 99cents!

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												McPixel will probably take you no more than two hours to beat. Its gameplay is very simplistic and at times kinda annoying. The scenarios and outcomes are immature and sophomoric. As you can see, there are a lot of reasons to not be interested in the game. With all that being said, I still enjoyed it. Yeah, it's all childish, but that doesn't stop it from being funny. It's also never "in your face" with its comedy. The comedy is presented deadpan, as if there's nothing funny or really out of the ordinary going on, which is the type of humor I love. Whether or not you'll enjoy McPixel really boils down to whether or not you're comfortable paying $1-5 for what is inherently a Newgrounds flash game.

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 24, 2015
												There is always some level of arbitrariness in a point & click.  Logically there might be a dozen ways to make a guard leave his post or to interact with a pump, but only one will be correct because of the artificial nature of the game.  A good point and click will keep this under control with reasonable puzzle solutions, while rewarding the player for their time and effort with humor, good music, an interesting story or other unique charm.  McPixel does none of this.  The music is short, repetitive, and not at all pleasing to listen to.  The puzzle solutions are arbitrary enough that all you can really do is click whatever is in the level until you manage to click the correct objects in the correct order.  It lacks a cohesive narrative.  There is humor, but it is crass and juvenile; even compared to other crass, juvenile humor, McPixel is in the back of the pack.There is no reason to buy this game at any price.  There will always be something better to spend your money on.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												I beat this game in 2 hours. I had fun for 30 minutes. McPixel is a game that ultimately relies on you to understand the "Moon Logic" joke of older 90's point-and-click games, and turns that joke into its big running gag. I didn't have a problem with it. The game made me laugh quite a few times for the unusual, inappropriate things McPixel would do with specific objects.However, that's as far as the gameplay extends. Beyond the mission-by-mission sequence, there's really little else to the game. Click on stuff, find the gag, move on. It's little more than that. And it gets old once you've played these levels over and over, to the point where finding another nonsensical answer would release another groan I had inside me.If you find this sort of humor funny, more power to you. If you find this gameplay as not monotonous, more power to you as well. For me, there's just very little to say about McPixel. It's short and funny, but not a very memorable or ultimately pleasant experience.

												McPixel can be quite funny and entertaining, but only for a short while. The outcomes and solutions to the puzzles are original and "out of the box", but that only goes so far. number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												McPixel is just a way to waste a couple of hours (two, in my case), nothing more.It's an humorous take on the Point & Click genre, but becomes boring very quickly once the surprise is gone. Its main problem is also its core mechanic : the solution to its puzzle makes no sense. This is what makes the game funny from time to time thanks to some absurd cutscenes, but this also means there is absolutely no reflexion required.In each of the 100 levels of the story mode (which doesn't have any scenario of course), you are asked to interact with all the items you can and combine them in all possible ways, until you find the "right" one (the one that doesn't make the stage explode). Discovering the intended combination doesn't feel particularly rewarding, because unlocking the "gold medal" in a stage (which unlocks bonus stages) requires to find ALL possible combinations. In the end, you will just find yourself clicking everywhere until the game congratulates you for completing the stage, and repeat the process until you reach the final cutscene.The only way I think this could be interesting is racing against a friend trying to get all levels done before the other. But in solo, McPixel is terribly empty.The game apparently comes with an editor to create your own stages and share them with the community. I must admit I didn't take the time to explore this mode, nor to test community-made stages, the game itself being so boring I doubt these stages can save it.To sum up, McPixel is a joke, as it was meant to be. But this jokes repeats itself a lot, making it feel terribly long (although the story mode takes two hours to complete), and five dollars seems to be too much for a spoof like this. This is typically the game you would expect to play for free in your browser to kill some time, this doesn't deserve a spot in your Steam library.

												 There's something that I think I should tell you all. I'm not feeling very well. And I haven't been for a while. Something inside me has jumped the track. I'm confused. I'm not thinking right. I'm not sleeping right. And I- Just don't think I am complaining about this or asking for your help. Because there's nothing anyone can do about it. It's just happened and that's all there is to it. But I don't know what I'm going to say from one minute to the next. I really don't. I don't know what I'm going to say and I don't know what I'm going to do. Do you understand that? And I know this is coming at a bad time for everyone but there's nothing I can do about that. I'm tired and I'm- I don't see things the way that I used to. Everything, everything, everything is ♥♥♥♥ing strange and it's all completely out of control and I'm frightened. And maybe if you all could give me some real help, you know? That would be- And not your pity or generosity but some help; Take a look at me. I know that I am ruining everything but I can't- If I don't say this now I may never say it. Everything is going very fast. It's going very, very fast. It's completely out of control. And if I don't say it today, tomorrow may be too late. I may be too crazy to even know how crazy I am. I don't know what to do. I don't know what to do. Something has happened to me and I'm very lost. And it doesn't stop. It's not getting better. I don't get better. I'm not getting better. It's just going on and it's going on. And there's nothing that I can do about it. It's not stopping. It's not stopping.

												Sorry, I didn't really care for this game. I didn't really get the humor, and that is definately what drives this game. Your goal is to stop a bomb hidden on the stage, so click on something and something will happen...maybe you'll win? I get the 80's TV trope of having mere seconds to stop a bomb being played out (and the name seems to be a "Macguyver" reference if I'm guessing right) but the humor fell flat for me. The game definately relies on a love of the absurd, and I could see it being a blast for some. If it's on sale or in a Humble Bundle, maybe give it a try if you are bored?

content:
Posted: July 15, 2013
												How do you explain McPixel? Its a throw back game with clunky graphics and a repeating theme song that reminds me of Mario. Game play is simple point and click with limited choices.So how is it so AWESOME! Might be my favorite game from the sale. The game is even better played with friends. Its not multiplayer. Have some friends gather around a pc or laptop, take turns guessing the actions, and then laugh out loud at each other. This game will be a cult classic. Sooner or later some college kids will turn it into a drinking game and it will take off. I expected to not like the game, wanted to lurk for cards, and ended up LOVING IT!! It is not your typical game. I take it as a tongue in cheek game that does weird things. If you ever watched Perferct Hair Forever, and liked that show, you can love McPixel.Buy it. Expect nothing from it, Play it with other people. Prepare to laugh, groan, argue, and laugh more.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2013
												7/10It's quite similar to Wario Ware (every level has a short time limit) except it's a little vulgar here and there.The humor and unexpected results are silly if not even ridiculous, but this game isn't supposed to be taken seriously anyway.Jump into a fire, get drunk and♥♥♥♥♥♥on an alien, kick the crap out of Pinocchio, get yourself caught in a Pokéball, anger Batman or focus on the main objective:DEFUSE THE DAMN BOMB! WHAT ARE YOU DOING WITH THAT SNOWBALL? WHY ARE YOU- oh, you threw it on the fuse, okay, well done, you saved the day.Also, failing IS an option, you still get to play through all levels.The "campaign" mode is pretty short and you'll finish it in 2 hours max, but there is some extra content that adds about the same amount of playtime.And of course you can replay your favorite chapters whenever you want.There even is a level editor (if you're one of those creative guys).

Posted: March 23, 2014
												Right off the bat, McPixel is a giant vat of What the Hell, with its distorted and random sense of humor and rapid-fire pacing. If anything, it's what happens when Adult Swim makes a point-and-click version of WarioWare for the NES.Your goal is to prevent a bomb from exploding by clicking stuff. There are a ton of levels and a ton of ways to interact with things, but there is only one solution; the rest trigger failure. Levels are split into chunks of about 5-7 scenarios, and the game loops through them, moving onto the next one if you fail. There's never a sense of punishment for failing to stop the bomb, as trial and error are part of the experience.The game has a mix of low-brow humor and non-sequiteur humor, and while it only made me laugh a few times, in general it was all endearing and tolerable. Adding to the mix is that the game in general is pretty short; one hour tops to beat it and another hour tops to 100-percent it. On top of that you've got additional level packs and the ability to create your own levels. It's a steal at lower prices, and the short length means it never overstays its welcome.McPixel isn't exactly replayable, but it's enough for a very good one-off and its features, while few, are well-designed.

Posted: July 29, 2013
												MCPIXEL!!! *Does a little jig*This game is the perfect 5 minute bash of randomness everyone needs in their life, just as you think you've seen everything McPixel has to offer it is bound to surprise you. The game is based around short 20 second point and click puzzles which make almost no sense at all. For example there may be a bomb in a shop, how do you dispose of it? Yep, just as you thought you feed it to an old man and watch his stomach contain the explosion... On top of all this randomness the art style is great and the music is just top notch! For the cheap entry prize I can't recommend this enough, especially if you have some friends over who are looking for a laugh!

Posted: March 4, 2014
												This game is not for the easly offended. I also would say that it's humor can be adult and crude at times. That being said, I still would recommend this games to older players. The point of the game is to find and disarm a bomb/explosion from going off. It's fast paced, only allowing 20 seconds per each 'stage'. A set of 5 stages per level in each chapter (chapter being made up of multiple levels). There are multiple endings per each stage, but only one true ending that ends with the explosion being disarmed. I won't spoil much more of the game, but if you like pixel art and enjoy adult humor then this game is for you. It's easy to pick up, but hard to put down.
