Posted: June 9, 2013
												That bomb is about to go off! Quick, you have 20 seconds to... oops. Too late. No time to wait, on to the next disaster! That's McPixel, a strange, strange game that mixes point and click puzzling with WarioWare-styled miniature scenarios. With no time to think and only a handful of clicks, you need to figure out how to disarm the situation before it goes up in smoke. I found it to be a fun, if simple title that had me falling over laughing at the gags and secrets scattered about. It's not that complicated, and at times it's absolutely childish, but it manages to ooze personality. For only a couple of bucks, you can't really go wrong.

Posted: August 23, 2013
												Think of it as an indie version of the WarioWare series: Short and quirky, but worth the price and pretty funny. Each level has only one solution and many ways to interact with the level, so it may or may not take some time to find the solution. Whether or not you find the solution, you're bound to find some mishap going on in the environment, which may cause for some good laughs. If you want to access the bonus levels, you actually have to find every single gag in each level. Some have a couple, while some have a lot. But with the "one click to conclusion" mechanic in the game, it shouldn't take long to find every single gag. I completed this game in a little over three hours, which isn't so bad for $5. If you wanna continue playing, there's an Endless Mode, a level editor, and "Free DLC," which is essentially user-made levels. If you don't wanna shell out for the full price, wait until a sale or a bundle comes along. But if you don't care, I say it's worth whatever price it's going for.

Posted: November 30, 2014
												Be forewarned, I am only through the first level of this game, but I am already hooked. This game is gloriously stupid, patently ridiculous, an absolutely hilarious. It's good enough to need three adverbs.You play as McPixel, I think, who is a MacGuyver/MacGruber type protagonist who only has thirty seconds to stop things from exploding. The gameplay is very simple point and click adventure style, the graphics are old school pixel art, and the music is something you expect from an Atari 2600 title, but all of it works perfectly together.The puzzles are simple, yet clever. It's worth getting them wrong just for the hilarity of the consequences. I've been slapped by Buddah, had a cow fall in love with me, fed a hot dog to a pot-smoking alien, and made a man poop dynamite in the span of five minutes. This game is absolutely worth $1.99. I haven't played long enough to know if it's worth the full price, but considering I've already laughed more at this than I would at most modern comedy movies in a theater, I'm going to tentatively say that yes. Yes it is. The developer has been really great about getting the word out about this game by giving out at least a couple hundred copies, and I really hope it pays off. I would definitely play more of his/her stuff.For a simple, funny, pick-up-an-go game, McPixel delivers. And then explodes. Often. I really can't overstate how many explosions you'll see in this game.

Posted: October 29, 2015
												Imagine WarioWare if it was point and click game from like, the 80s. You control the titular mcpixel in what appears to be the climax of every action movie imaginable. Well, every action movie that involves a ticking bomb anyway. To "save the day" as this little game puts it, you interact with the world around you until you simultaneously locate and neutralize the explosives. If you screw up, you're dropped in, pants or not, another puzzle, barely given enough time to register what went wrong, kinda like college. Succed and you're rewarded with a shiny square, also just like college. Screw up on the same task in every way possible and you'll get an even shinier gold square, just like politics.What makes this game stand out from the "minigame army" genre is that McPixel is so completely insane, marvel wants to give him a healing factor. You could make the most innocuous maneuver and McP could start pummeling a child with a toilet or something. No, that in particular does not happen, surprisingly. What does happen is frenching the President, kicking basically everyone in the groin and convincing an American soldier you're his superior by stealing his hatThe five bucks this game costs is about what you'd pay for a dirty joke book or something like that and that's essentially the sort of entertainment you'll get out of this game. Crude, tasteless but you can't help but laugh every so often.

Posted: August 31, 2015
												Basically Warioware as a point-and-click adventure game where you need to stop something from exploding, and it's not always obvious WHAT is going to explode. It's wacky, zany nonsense-filled comedy gameplay, which means it's best not to play too much at one time. High-octane comedy has a habit of getting old if you don't take breaks.Two big issues I have with it: first, there's a handful of rules that aren't really explained. Once you pick up an item, there's no way to put it down, and you can't hold more then one item. If you click on something that causes you to do something - ANYTHING other than pick an item up - the stage ends, whether or not the effect did anything about the bomb of the level.The other issue: your reward for 100% completion is a really crappy final bonus level. Everything else was really fun, but this one level left a very bad taste in my mouth afterwards.I'd recommend picking up this game, but as you can see, I beat everything in 9 hours, and I think 2 of those hours were just me loitering in the "chatroom" waiting for someone else to show up. Hard to say if $5 is worth that, but then, how bad can you really waste $5?

Posted: August 8, 2015
												McPixel is best described as a trial and error based point and click adventure. The humor isn't very sophisticated and centers mostly around kicking, humping and blowing things up. It's just the right thing to air out the brain for 5 minutes and enter a state of braindeadedded bliss. There isn't much else to say, the story mode doesn't really feature a story, you go around clicking through screens till you've found all possible endings - that's it. As a bonus there are some "free DLCs" which are hit-or-miss, a endless mode, which basically repeates the screens of the story mode and a "fart along" feature, which is amusing for a minute, but not particularly noteworth. It is amusing if you can enjoy crude, simple humor. It only costs 4€ and at that price I'd would buy it again. I loved it.

Posted: July 23, 2013
												This is a weird "game". Most of the puzzles make no sense at all, so the only option is to try everything until the level succeeds. The point of the game is that every interaction is completely unexpected and funny.There are usually from 3 to 5 objects in one level and about one of them can be picked up and used for interacting with the rest of the objects. One or two interactions can take place on each level until you either win or lose it. A typical puzzle goes like this: you are in a plane with a nuclear bomb, a snake and a shovel. If you click the bomb, the snake tries to eat it but cannot, because it's too big. If you click the snake, it bites you and the bomb explodes meanwhile. The solution is to pick up the shovel and then click the bomb, at which point McPixel uses the shovel to shove the bomb down the snake's throat (if snakes can be said to have throats), and then the bomb safely explodes in the snake's belly.

Posted: March 23, 2014
												Right off the bat, McPixel is a giant vat of What the Hell, with its distorted and random sense of humor and rapid-fire pacing. If anything, it's what happens when Adult Swim makes a point-and-click version of WarioWare for the NES.Your goal is to prevent a bomb from exploding by clicking stuff. There are a ton of levels and a ton of ways to interact with things, but there is only one solution; the rest trigger failure. Levels are split into chunks of about 5-7 scenarios, and the game loops through them, moving onto the next one if you fail. There's never a sense of punishment for failing to stop the bomb, as trial and error are part of the experience.The game has a mix of low-brow humor and non-sequiteur humor, and while it only made me laugh a few times, in general it was all endearing and tolerable. Adding to the mix is that the game in general is pretty short; one hour tops to beat it and another hour tops to 100-percent it. On top of that you've got additional level packs and the ability to create your own levels. It's a steal at lower prices, and the short length means it never overstays its welcome.McPixel isn't exactly replayable, but it's enough for a very good one-off and its features, while few, are well-designed.

Posted: March 23, 2014
												Right off the bat, McPixel is a giant vat of What the Hell, with its distorted and random sense of humor and rapid-fire pacing. If anything, it's what happens when Adult Swim makes a point-and-click version of WarioWare for the NES.Your goal is to prevent a bomb from exploding by clicking stuff. There are a ton of levels and a ton of ways to interact with things, but there is only one solution; the rest trigger failure. Levels are split into chunks of about 5-7 scenarios, and the game loops through them, moving onto the next one if you fail. There's never a sense of punishment for failing to stop the bomb, as trial and error are part of the experience.The game has a mix of low-brow humor and non-sequiteur humor, and while it only made me laugh a few times, in general it was all endearing and tolerable. Adding to the mix is that the game in general is pretty short; one hour tops to beat it and another hour tops to 100-percent it. On top of that you've got additional level packs and the ability to create your own levels. It's a steal at lower prices, and the short length means it never overstays its welcome.McPixel isn't exactly replayable, but it's enough for a very good one-off and its features, while few, are well-designed.

Posted: March 21, 2014
												McPixel is pretty short but quite funny if you enjoy raunchy nonsense.Definitely not everyone's sense of humour but I can't imagine anyone being that upset about the price tag. That is, if it were on sale. I believe the regular price on this game is $5 at the moment  and if you want to support the developer that's your prerogative. My advice would be to spend less than that on it though.Each level is a different scenario that puts the responsibility of preventing an explosive from detonating (or equivalent disaster). A mouse only game, you click on one of the various items in the scenario, McPixel interacts with it, and you hope for the best. The humour usually lies in what happens if McPixel DOESN'T prevent the disaster.There are several levels to play through and in each one two endings to aim for, either a win or specifically funny outcome. The whole game can be completed in a relatively short sitting, maybe 3 hours of straight play. I wouldn't recommend this though since the quickly moving and sometimes flashing backgrounds can be hard on the eyes. The music can also become grating since it repeats mostly the same one track. A saving grace may be that the first time you hear that track you will probably like it.In summation it is a fun experience and I would recommend this to a friend who isn't offended by the idea of a man pleasuring a giraffe to completion. Still, the $5 price tag may cause buyers remorse especially if you don't smile at the idea of manual giraffe gratification. Buy it for less.

Posted: January 1, 2014
												LOL, ROFL. This game is a point and click adventure with a great sense of humor. If this game refunded every person that didn't laugh at least once through a play through they would nearly never have to issue a refund. The game is based more on luck than logic; though, the cut scenes that debunk your logical decisions are much of the premise of the humor.The game takes roughly 1-2 hours to 100% the story (depending on how many cut scenes you skip) and about an hour to 100% the 10 free dlc courses (more should be coming soon). Additionally, if you feel at any point that this game is too easy to 100% go play Nerdpack in the dlc and try to 100% it :P. The game doesn't have much replay value after the initial play through, but between endless mode and new dlc there is still the potential. For the price of this game it is a great deal.

Posted: October 3, 2012
												If you've ever played one of the  Wario Ware or Four Second Frenzy flash games, imagine that in a point-and-click adventure framework with a sense of humor like Spongebob without an age rating limitation. Add explosions every few seconds, and BOOM you get McPixel. It's pretty fun as something of a series of mini-cartoons your first time through levels, and it's good as a microgames style challenge if you challenge Endless Mode.There's free DLC (both user-made and official), a level editor, and a number of unlockables as you go. Definitely worth playing if you like a healthy dose of silly. (And there is an official free version that's not on Steam if you go looking for it and just want to try the game.)

Posted: July 19, 2013
												McPixel is funny in the way that fart jokes and poop are. You'll be surprised at what the game does, as it gleefully has you pee, vomit, and crap your way through puzzles. The Warioware-styled "minigames" are extremely varied and creative, although at times you'll wonder what you actually did that solved the problem. Somewhere along the way, you'll find yourself amused by the antics of this red-shirted public urinator, and McPixel really is a fairly clever game underneath its bawdy exterior.

Posted: November 28, 2013
												McPixel is funny, random, and usually nonsensical fun times in game form.McPixel is also incredibly short, has almost no replay value, and is ultimately forgetable for $5 (compared to the $3 it goes for on the iOS).You can literally get the full experience by watching it on Youtube. The extra features you get by finding every possible ending to a level don't really add anything to the game. There is a level editor though so take that as you will.McPixel just feels better off as a free flash game than a full length (ha) purchase. And that's why I have trouble justifying purchasing it.

Posted: July 6, 2013
												I'm assuming McPixel is some sort of parody of MacGyver. It's point and click, and the goal of the game is to figure out how to prevent a bomb from blowing up the level. It's not a real puzzle game because the game has no logic. The whole game is just stupid and silly and full of toilet humor. The only way to win is through trial and error. It's more or less just a joke game of seemingly endless parodies and nonsensical solutions. If dumb is your style, you can't get much dumber than McPixel.

Posted: October 24, 2013
												This is just another insane game I own, and it was well worth the money. It feels like a throw back for me to the old C64 games (Yes, I had a C128 that played C64 games), which makes it highly enjoyable for me. The game is VERY challenging and things you think will work to disarm the bomb do not always work. You may find yourself wanting to rage quit at parts, but then you get ove rit and laugh at how stupid the answer to disarming the bomb was. To me, McPixel was worth every penny! Plus the free DLC in the game is a riot!

Posted: December 30, 2012
												The dumbest game ever made... In the best way imaginable.There are four chapters. each broken up into 3 rounds, and each round containing a handful of levels. In each level there's a bomb and you have thirty seconds to defuse it. This is harder then it seems though, because the world of McPixel makes no sense whatsoever. Depending on the level, diffusing the bomb can be accomplished by peeing on it, feeding it to a stoned alien, or sacrificing yourself to a volcano god. The only way to know what to do on any given level is trial and error, but that's the name of the game: exploration! It's always hilarious to see what happens next. A great game for someone with a super off-beat sense of humor with ten minutes to kill here and there.

Posted: December 28, 2013
												Oh, Mcpixel, Mcpixel, Mcpixel, why are you so weird? This is honestly the 2nd weirdest game I have ever played (the 1st being the WarioWare games)! Mcpixel is an obscure, weird-♥♥♥ little Indie game where the goal is to neutralize a hidden bomb within 20 seconds, but also to f**k around and see all the weird options you can choose between peeing on a bomb, face-palming yourself with a hot-dog, standing over a fire with a ukulele to make a rain dance, inserting a light-saber into your mouth and then hover (don't you dare make a joke about that), to mutating Mario, to noticing the Space Core from Portal 2 in the background, to making PewDiePie rage after he stares at a barrel, to lip-locking Obama...........Did I mention this game is weird? But hey, that's what makes this such an awesome game: It's weird! There's even a mini game where the goal is to literally fart to the tune....EAT YOUR HEART OUT, GUITAR HERO!!!!! Trust me, it's easier to see what I mean when you actually play it rather than just hear me talk about it. So go! Play it! It's awesome! Stop reading this and go play it!.................................................................................................................................................................................................................................YOU GUYS ARE STILL HERE?!?!?!?!?!?!?

												Meet McPixel - a seemingly simple youth with the unfortunate job of saving the world in realistic conditions. There are various objects to click on, and McPixel will interact in a number of different ways; these are often violent and somtimes result in the detonation.Little is known of the character of McPixel until the very end of the game, whereupon a storyline begins to take shape and everything in the game makes perfect sense.

Posted: July 7, 2014
												McPixel is the kind of game that will cause you to just stare at the screen with only one thought in your head: "What the ♥♥♥♥?"Ridicolously random, in every level you will need to save the world by defusing a deadly bomb. How, you ask? Well, you could stick up a cow's♥♥♥♥♥ hit an old guy in the balls so he picks it up and flies away with it, pee on aliens, hit batman with a frying pan, and... well, you get the idea.There is no pattern or logic behind the levels, neither any explaination. You just click on whatever's clickable and see if it's the right thing. Right? You saved the world! Wrong? You blew everything up. It's that simple.McPixel is not a bad game, but it is quite pointless. It is good for about an hour of giggling and randomness, but nothing more than that. It's obviously not meant to be serious, and I definately understand the humor behind it, but... it's just not good as a game. You just click stuff and see if things blow up or not, that's it.And with a price of $5... not really sure if it's worth.

												I'm about to describe a solution to a level, but I feel it is the only way to really appreciate the humor, weirdness and wonderful options you have in this game.You are standing on the edge of a volcano. Etched into the side is "INSERT VIRGIN" You are faced with a bone, a cow, and a woman. You have 20 seconds to save the day.Option 1: I click the bone, then the cow: McPixel inserts the bone into the cow. The cow emits hearts. The volcano blows up.Option 2: I click the bone, then the woman: McPixel shakes the bone at the woman like she is a dog, then turns and throws the bone into the volcano. The woman leaps after the bone into the lava. The volcano blows up.Option 3: I click on the volcano. McPixel throws himself into the lava. The day is saved.If that didn't make you want to buy this game, then nothing will.

Posted: December 2, 2013
												A perfect sorbet to cleanse the palate between mind-wrenchers, McPixel is the ultimate in un-puzzle games. Straddling the fine line between Zen and Beavis-and-Butthead-grade toilet humor, McPixel throws you into a high-speed gauntlet of idiotic scenarios, almost all of which involve some manner of high explosive about to go off. Using every resource available (examples of which include dynamite, cows, balloons, vodka, firearms, more dynamite, and an endless supply of kicks to the groin), you must disarm the danger within 20 seconds and save the day. Or, failing that, die in a hilarious and moronic way.Separating it from the usual Wario Ware clone, there's little logic to any of the game's many stages; more often than not you'll muddle your way through by clicking random things and getting lucky. When an actual sense of challenge DOES arise, it's usually due to the necessary key object being barely visible. What saves McPixel from being a completely unjustified waste of time is the fact that it's one of the funniest casual titles you're going to find anywhere. Admittedly, it's extremely low-brow, but my first time playing it basically amounted to 3 hours of near-brainless clicking broken up by a constant stream of disgusted, wonderful laughter. Somehow, the combination of Gary Larson-style cows and humans rendered in 8-bit graphics with 4th grade toilet humor works amazingly well, and after clearing each level correctly I had no problem going back and trying to find every idiotic failure cutscene in order to achieve a 100% completion. It's not the sort of game you'll want to discuss with coworkers around the (likely to explode) water cooler, but sometimes you just need to shut your brain off and laugh as some jerk kicks Batman in the nards a few dozen times, y'know?

												A very silly and simple game, the entire objective of each level is to find the bomb hidden within 5-10 seconds in order to prevent it from going off. Unfortunately this means this game is entirely trial and error, you have to click on various things in the background and hope that it somehow relates to the bomb being disposed of, and sometimes the solution is incredibly unclear. Posted: November 30, 2014
												Be forewarned, I am only through the first level of this game, but I am already hooked. This game is gloriously stupid, patently ridiculous, an absolutely hilarious. It's good enough to need three adverbs.You play as McPixel, I think, who is a MacGuyver/MacGruber type protagonist who only has thirty seconds to stop things from exploding. The gameplay is very simple point and click adventure style, the graphics are old school pixel art, and the music is something you expect from an Atari 2600 title, but all of it works perfectly together.The puzzles are simple, yet clever. It's worth getting them wrong just for the hilarity of the consequences. I've been slapped by Buddah, had a cow fall in love with me, fed a hot dog to a pot-smoking alien, and made a man poop dynamite in the span of five minutes. This game is absolutely worth $1.99. I haven't played long enough to know if it's worth the full price, but considering I've already laughed more at this than I would at most modern comedy movies in a theater, I'm going to tentatively say that yes. Yes it is. The developer has been really great about getting the word out about this game by giving out at least a couple hundred copies, and I really hope it pays off. I would definitely play more of his/her stuff.For a simple, funny, pick-up-an-go game, McPixel delivers. And then explodes. Often. I really can't overstate how many explosions you'll see in this game.

Posted: August 31, 2015
												Basically Warioware as a point-and-click adventure game where you need to stop something from exploding, and it's not always obvious WHAT is going to explode. It's wacky, zany nonsense-filled comedy gameplay, which means it's best not to play too much at one time. High-octane comedy has a habit of getting old if you don't take breaks.Two big issues I have with it: first, there's a handful of rules that aren't really explained. Once you pick up an item, there's no way to put it down, and you can't hold more then one item. If you click on something that causes you to do something - ANYTHING other than pick an item up - the stage ends, whether or not the effect did anything about the bomb of the level.The other issue: your reward for 100% completion is a really crappy final bonus level. Everything else was really fun, but this one level left a very bad taste in my mouth afterwards.I'd recommend picking up this game, but as you can see, I beat everything in 9 hours, and I think 2 of those hours were just me loitering in the "chatroom" waiting for someone else to show up. Hard to say if $5 is worth that, but then, how bad can you really waste $5?

Posted: March 5, 2014
												McPixel is a point-and-click adventure game. Sort of. The basic premise is that you have 20 seconds to defuse a bomb in each scenario, with various things you can click on to get various outcomes. However, there are some real problems with it:1) There is no logic to the solution. It's really annoying as it's just trial and error until you get the right solution, which gets really dull really fast. 2) One of points of the game is it's humour. Except it's really not very funny. It's just "gags" most of which involve McPixel hitting or grabbing something and then dying 'comically'. It's just stupid, and not even in a ridiculous cartoon humour way. I played most of the 1st chapter and in that whole time there was one joke that I found remotely amusing.Admittedly, I gave up on the game relatively early on, so it may get better later on, but I really don't think that's much of a selling point. I guess the best thing I can say about it is that it's really cheap, but there are far better free games out there, so again, that hardly works in the game's favour. Even at the low price, it's hard to recommend it. I paid about 50p for it in a sale, and even at that price, I feel like it's only just worth it. Overall, give this a miss, and spend your money on something better.

Posted: March 4, 2014
												This game is not for the easly offended. I also would say that it's humor can be adult and crude at times. That being said, I still would recommend this games to older players. The point of the game is to find and disarm a bomb/explosion from going off. It's fast paced, only allowing 20 seconds per each 'stage'. A set of 5 stages per level in each chapter (chapter being made up of multiple levels). There are multiple endings per each stage, but only one true ending that ends with the explosion being disarmed. I won't spoil much more of the game, but if you like pixel art and enjoy adult humor then this game is for you. It's easy to pick up, but hard to put down.

												Nonsensical WarioWare wannabe on crack for the PC?Juvenile and pointed deconstruction of the point and click adventure genre?Maybe both?Maybe just nonsense for the sake of nonsense? Me and my significant other burned through McPixel's Story Mode, most of the hidden stages unlocked by finding all the gags, and all available free DLC in about two hours in one night, and odds are you will too. There isn't a lot to McPixel's design other than finding absurd solutions to each 20-second stage and watching the solutions or failures play out. One or two clicks will be enough to know if you've succeeded or failed, and there's really not a lot of logic to what you'll be doing and interactions are rarely ever what you'd expect. The humor may be a bit to juvenile for some and the overall premise far too simplistic to warrant a full-price purchase, but I've honestly spent two hours entertaining myself with much worse than than the otherwordly silliness this pixelated and crude mess has to offer.

Posted: June 12, 2014
												I am both satisfied and disappointed by McPixel.I watched few gameplays some time ago and thought it is a pretty dumb game. But I eventually ended up buying it in a sale and decided to play it, since I didn´t remember any of the solutions.What suprised me and what I really appreciate is humor in the game. I actually laughed hard about some of the gags and the end got me completely. It might seem like if it had stupid humor for wierd people, but the fact that it´s so straightforward and unbridled makes it very enjoyable experience for those with at least some sense of humor.What kills the fun, unfortunately, is poor design of some of the levels. Chapters 1-3 are generally good, but Chapter 4 feels sometimes too random, with solutions making no sense as well as gags with no inspiration. DLC is where true fun completely disappears, where the gameplay becomes just a random click-fest and gags are mostly recycled from the story mode (but it´s a free DLC, so one can´t complain too much about that).McPixel also contains some extras - tried them - didn´t like them. What´s nice is that you can create your own levels, with customized backgrounds, items and gags. Sadly, you can´t share them whenever you want. Steam workshop could be really nice here, but I suppose there is some reason devs don´t want players to publish levels without control.Endless mode is just a revisitation of story mode levels and that means McPixel lacks replayability for most of the playerbase.I´m unsure if I can recommend the game. For me, it was more enjoyable then disappointing afterall, but not everyone will enjoy it. If you are interested, check few minutes of some gameplay and if you are still not decided after that, leave it or wait for some decent discount.***** 6/10***** 60%

Posted: March 4, 2016
												It's silly, it's fast, it's highly and overtly referential, while also somehow (mostly) making pixel hunting sort of entertaining. If you're interested in an absurd, light point and click adventure game, you can't exactly go wrong here. Simply go in expecting to have to retry puzzles several times as you try to click everything to figure out the bizarre logic of the game, but absolutely don't expect any sort of cohesive, profound stories here. This is a silly absurd romp for those times when you want to see ridiculous things unfold without having to bear through loads of story setup or progression, and in that it's sort of wonderful. It's also somewhat replayable with a few hidden things in each area, as I recall, but these never struck me as worth going after.

Posted: July 2, 2016
												TL/DR - On it's own terms, I'd give it a 8/10 with a 6/10 overall.  NTL/R:Gather round, children, and I'll tell you a tell of gaming in the year of our lord nineteen hundred and eigthy four.  You see, back then, games HAD to rely on uniqueness to stand out.  Some where unique by having great graphics, others through innovative game play, while still others by challenge and re-playability.  In this age there came a game, on an ancient machine known only as a C64, a game called "Cliff Hanger".  It had the audacity to stand out by having something of a sense of humour and somewhat hazy rules that you had to suss out through exploration.   Comprised of a "scene", each level had to be explored and the rules and ways of beating it had to be discovered.  Failure simply meant that you watched fail animation that kind of made you smile.  And then this idea was lost to time, not quite enough to become legend, not too little to be utterly forgotten by those who were there.Lost, that is, until now.McPixel is a game about failure.  It's a game about exploration, and, ultimately, a game that you will step away from glad that you bought it.  The humour is on point, the presentation is solid, the music is engaging, and game play in interesting; it is worth the money the dev is charging.  It's not going to affect you, or change how you see gaming or narriative, or any of this, it's just solid, fun, silly game play.Pros----- The graphical style is great retro-inspired chunky pixels- It's pretty comical, with surprising outcomes for various actions- Simple, stupid, funCons------ Once you've beaten it, you're probably not going back- It's definitely not for everyone.  Hardcores will probably not enjoy it at all.There's really not much more to be said about it.  On it's own terms, I'd give it a 8/10.

Posted: July 28, 2013
												I'm about to describe a solution to a level, but I feel it is the only way to really appreciate the humor, weirdness and wonderful options you have in this game.You are standing on the edge of a volcano. Etched into the side is "INSERT VIRGIN" You are faced with a bone, a cow, and a woman. You have 20 seconds to save the day.Option 1: I click the bone, then the cow: McPixel inserts the bone into the cow. The cow emits hearts. The volcano blows up.Option 2: I click the bone, then the woman: McPixel shakes the bone at the woman like she is a dog, then turns and throws the bone into the volcano. The woman leaps after the bone into the lava. The volcano blows up.Option 3: I click on the volcano. McPixel throws himself into the lava. The day is saved.If that didn't make you want to buy this game, then nothing will.

Posted: July 23, 2013
												This is a weird "game". Most of the puzzles make no sense at all, so the only option is to try everything until the level succeeds. The point of the game is that every interaction is completely unexpected and funny.There are usually from 3 to 5 objects in one level and about one of them can be picked up and used for interacting with the rest of the objects. One or two interactions can take place on each level until you either win or lose it. A typical puzzle goes like this: you are in a plane with a nuclear bomb, a snake and a shovel. If you click the bomb, the snake tries to eat it but cannot, because it's too big. If you click the snake, it bites you and the bomb explodes meanwhile. The solution is to pick up the shovel and then click the bomb, at which point McPixel uses the shovel to shove the bomb down the snake's throat (if snakes can be said to have throats), and then the bomb safely explodes in the snake's belly.
